Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube Building Blocks: Collaborative Proposal: GeoLink - Leveraging Semantics and Linked Data for Data Sharing and Discovery in the Geosciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work addresses a challenge central to the EarthCube program's success: How to employ state of the art technology for geoscience data discovery, access, and integration. The project brings together significant geosciences holdings in the ocean, earth and polar sciences to demonstrate how innovative technologies can be robustly applied to these facilities to enhance the capabilities for scientists to discover and interpret relevant geoscience data and knowledge. The end product, GEOLink, will lower barriers to cross-repository data discovery and access, while respecting and preserving repository autonomy and heterogeneity. They will demonstrate the approach through a portal that allows searching and browsing of integrated content from multiple repositories.

A key challenge for EarthCube is to enable data discovery, access, and integration in a sustainable way. Existing data repositories and networks must be linked, while retaining their independent missions and services to existing disciplinary communities. Cultural, conceptual, and infrastructural heterogeneities must be respected in order to maintain different perspectives and differing priorities and thus foster inclusivity in the EarthCube endeavor. In particular, individual choices made by providers of data or repositories will need to be respected in an inclusive manner, and approaches to integration must reflect this. At the same time, however, the diversity and heterogeneity of geoscience data presents a significant barrier to its discovery. In this project, the researchers involved will develop a demonstration called GEOLink based on: 1) digital publication of geoscience data and knowledge as "Linked Open Data"; combined with 2) semantic integration using design patterns and vocabularies shared among federated repositories; and 3) an underlying cyberinfrastructure extendable in both depth and breadth, that can become a central building block for EarthCube data harmonization. The cyberinfrastructure underlying the approach is extendable, sustainable, and affordable - leveraging state of the art developments in Linked Open Data and formal semantics, grounded through shared Ontology Design Patterns. GEOLink-enabled repositories will support discovery of related resources, including Rolling Deck to Repository (R2R), the Biological and Chemical Oceanographic Data Management Office (BCO-DMO), Integrated Earth Data Applications (IEDA), the Long-Term Ecological Research Network (LTER), DataONE, and the International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP), as well content from other EarthCube Building Block projects and collaborators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists need data-- measurements of diverse aspects of the environment--in order to better understand and predict the behavior of the Earth System. While much data about the environment has been and continues to be collected by NSF supported researchers, it is currently very difficult to gather these together from various projects and different regions, in order to do more powerful and accurate analyses and syntheses.

To address this problem, the National Science Foundation's EarthCube program has set out to create integrated data infrastructures across the Geosciences. One of the key challenges for such an infrastructure is to simplify the processes by which researchers can share, discover, and reuse scientific data. In order to achieve this, existing Earth Science data repositories and networks must be more readily accessible through a common framework, while also allowing them to retain their independent missions and specialized services to existing disciplinary communities. Cultural, conceptual, and infrastructural heterogeneities must be respected in order to maintain different perspectives, topics, and data granularities, and thus foster inclusivity in the EarthCube endeavor. At the same time, however, these considerations raise significant technological barriers for cross-repository data discovery and reuse. The primary goal of the GeoLink collaboration was to investigate how Semantic Web and Linked Open Data technologies might lower these barriers, by streamlining and harmonizing access to geoscience data housed in multiple, 'autonomous' earth science data repositories. 

The GeoLink project advanced the creation of a common cyberinfrastructure by addressing challenges in 1) the digital publication of geoscience data and knowledge as Linked Open Data; in conjunction with 2) semantic integration of the data, achieved through descriptions based on common ontology design patterns and vocabularies; to 3) enable an interoperable, lightweight, common cyberinfrastructure federating data resource discovery across participating NSF-sponsored earth science data repositories.  
 
The project created a GeoLink Vocabulary, and Knowledgebase, using a Linked Open Data approach, that unified descriptions of many aspects of scientific data, ranging from details about aspects of marine research vessel's deployment and mission, to the roles that scientists play on projects, and how these projects are funded. The development of this vocabulary involved defining both the terms and their relationships, based on common ontology design patterns developed over the course of the project.  An example would be formally expressing in a semantic web language (RDF) that a research "cruise" takes place on a "vessel" traversing a "trajectory", and has a "chief scientist". The vocabulary is then used to describe data resources in the participating repositories, leading to creation of the GeoLink KnowledgeBase that currently consists of over 48.5 million assertions semantically describing the collective data holdings. Over the course of the project, computational challenges arose and were resolved, in rapidly resolving web-based queries issued over such a large knowledgebase. The GeoLink Vocabulary and Knowledgebase provide a sound semantic basis for building advanced Web-based searches. Some demonstration prototypes using the Knowledgebase can be explored at http://geolink.org.  
  
The GeoLink project demonstrated the feasibility of building a lightweight, extendable, and affordable common cyberinfrastructure. Note, however, that there are no inherent limits on the topical areas that can be described and modeled in the GeoLink vocabulary, making the approach of potentially broad applicability throughout the earth sciences. 
  
The vision of GeoLink's Knowledgebase approach is currently being further extended through ongoing work sponsored by NSF's EarthCube. As vocabulary development proceeds further, the Linked Open Data mechanisms for federating data repositories, as explored by the GeoLink project, should greatly assist researchers in sharing and accessing one another's data across the Web, with minimal need for restructuring complex databases, and potentially deep discovery and consistent interpretation of data resources.  As a consequence, the pace of scientific discovery will accelerate, and the potential for validation and extension of scientific insights will be enhanced.
